captions.text:
I like to think I&#39;m always keen to try new
things, as long as it doesn&#39;t involve my bottom.

Trust me, whatever you think I&#39;m missing out
on, I&#39;m quite content with the maximum amount

of entertainment value that can be extracted
from my butthole being doing crosswords on
the toilet.

Nobody else is talking about your butthole,
Yahtz.
I KNOW I&#39;M JUST SAYING.

Anyway, the point is, I&#39;d never played a Dragon
Quest game before but I thought I&#39;d give the
new one a go.

Which obviously means I can&#39;t say if it&#39;s
a good Dragon Quest game but I can certainly

compare it to other games and to objects being
pushed up my butthole.

One thing I did know about Dragon Quest going
in is that Japanese people go double downward
dog bonkers for it.

Like, &quot;unofficial public holiday every time
one comes out&quot; bonkers, putting it in impact

terms right up there with terrorist strikes
and dead princesses.

But having played Dragon Quest XI: Echoes
of an Elusive Age, and yes I am so going to

slowly pervert that subtitle as this review
goes on, I am now slightly concerned about

the Japanese, as I would about a school friend
who confides that they have a crush on the
dinner lady.

Knowing they&#39;re going to be driven to suicide
by mockery within a week.
By me.

Like the dinner lady Dragon Quest&#39;s appeal
seems to lie in it being a nice, comfortable,

unthreatening place always good for an extra
helping of dumplings if you put in the right
words.

The plot of Dragon Quest XI: Emissions of
an Infected Arse is, you are in generic JRPG

swords and sorcery fantasy world, east of
Java.

You are the last surviving heir of a deposed
royal house who was found as a baby and adopted

by peasant farmers, there&#39;s a weird birthmark
on your hand that magic occasionally comes

out of and you grow into a strong handsome
lad with a girl&#39;s haircut, so when you come

of age your adoptive parent takes you aside
and says &quot;Look, let&#39;s not beat around the

bush, you couldn&#39;t be more obviously a destined
fantasy hero if your high school graduation
picture was painted by Boris Vallejo.

Sadly there doesn&#39;t seem to be any global
crisis going on at the moment that would require

a destined hero, so why don&#39;t you just wander
around the countryside for a bit and destiny
will presumably strike at some point.&quot;

I&#39;m not being dismissive, here, that&#39;s literally
how we start.

You go to the royal castle on the off chance
that a kidnapped princess needs rescuing but

get thrown in the dungeon &#39;cos the king&#39;s
played too many Elder Scrolls games and thinks
that&#39;s just what you do with destined heroes.

We break out within minutes and the plot becomes
&quot;go from city to city looking for the person

who isn&#39;t one of the five or six endlessly
repeated NPC models, recruit them to your

party then do whatever they want to do until
the next one comes along.&quot;

By this method we enlist to our cause a toddler,
two hotties, an old man, a comedy stereotype
of a homosexual and an actual homosexual.

And after the last party member joins they
say &quot;What do you mean, destiny hasn&#39;t struck
yet?

Alright, let&#39;s just gather the six destiny
balls, that&#39;ll wake the fucker up.&quot;

I only had three or four days to play the
game in so I was under no illusion that I&#39;d

finish the fucking thing, and I dropped out
after the third or fourth ball, about twenty
hours in and still no sign of a big villain.

Couple of Darth Vaders but no Palpatines,
y&#39;know.

But you can see what I mean about comfortable
and non-threatening.
At least the plot is.
Couldn&#39;t say the same for the visual design.

The characters all remind me of those anime
cosplayers who wear masks with anime faces
drawn on to look more open quotes &#39;authentic.&#39;

The kind that look like, if you woke in the
night and saw them at the foot of your bed

it&#39;d be the last thing you experienced before
blackness and the sound of tearing cartilage.
Well, let&#39;s be accepting of cultural differences.

Which are presumably why pressing start doesn&#39;t
open the pause menu but turns on &#39;autorun&#39;
mode.

I wouldn&#39;t think an autorun mode would be
much use in an RPG, the overworld can be big

but it&#39;s full of random encounters so it&#39;s
not like you can just point yourself at your

destination and then nip off for a quick tea
ceremony.

Gameplay wise, Dragon Quest XI: Errors of
an Ilicit Anus embodies a nostalgic &quot;If it

ain&#39;t broke don&#39;t mentally progress past the
age of twelve&quot; attitude with a simple, heavily
text-based retro turn-based combat system.

Although you can move your character freely
around the battle space, possibly as a joke.

It seems to be a feature put in for very superstitious
people who want to convince themselves that

serpentining will actually affect whether
or not Malicious Chimp A will whiff his Handful
of Faeces attack.

Or for very easily amused people who want
to stand behind the enemy during battle so

that their alert, hunched forward pose can
become part of a hilarious suggestive tableau.

The funny thing about random battles in Dragon
Quest XI: Elegies of Eddie the Eagle Edwards

is that you only ever get into them because
you choose to.

Random enemies only notice you if you accidentally
stumble up one of their nostrils and you can
run faster than them anyway.

Even during the what I will only call &quot;stealth
sections&quot; if a small dog nervously pissing

on a cello is a &quot;string quartet&quot;, the armed
fanatics convinced that you are the spawn

of Satan get winded and stop pursuing you
after chasing you the approximate length of
my dick.

You can literally sprint unmolested through
an entire dungeon and back just to use the
save point before you take on the boss.

But if you don&#39;t get into random battles,
then you&#39;ll be severely underlevelled for

the fights you have to do, so while the game
doesn&#39;t force us to run a gauntlet of cricket

bats to the arse, it has laid a cricket bat
down in front of us and locked the door with

a special mechanism that will only open if
we fill a jar with our tears.

I think it&#39;s fair to say that Dragon Quest
XI: Erections of an Aggressive Emu isn&#39;t going

to light any fires as an innovative or challenging
work, I mean it&#39;s not even halfheartedly clicking

an empty barbecue lighter, but that&#39;s precisely
not what it&#39;s setting out to do, and you know
what, I think I respect that.

As I sailed inexorably through this entirely
obvious plot,

that at times feels like we&#39;re playing a D&amp;D
campaign that the DM is making up on the spot

in the brief moments when he can get off the
phone to his divorce lawyer, visiting the

standard environments - grasslands, desert,
ocean, grasslands, grasslands, ocean again

- fighting twee monsters that all seem carefully
designed to be potentially made into plushies

to sell on Etsy, I felt myself being taken
in.

I was sinking down into a cozy warm bath where
I could doze blissfully off to a fluffy dream

world where no perceptions are being challenged
but everything&#39;s just nice.

But I think it worth mentioning that I could
only enter this state after I had muted the
music.

Or, to give it its proper name, the FUCKING
music.

Yeah, I get the game&#39;s dedicated to the retro
nostalgia thing, hence the bleep bloop 8-bit

battle sounds, and that&#39;s why a lot of the
music sounds like it came from a 16-bit era

midi synthesizer, but it also sounds like
someone took that synthesizer, turned the

BLARP setting to 100% and proceeded to stomp
on it like a grape in a French vineyard.

It&#39;s minute-long loop after minute-long loop
of string and brass sections honking like
pigs queueing up to have their throats slit.

Let that be the lesson, viewers: cozy a place
as the past may seem, don&#39;t forget it also

contains potato famines, Hitler and synth
music.
